body:
@ardeal --workers use CPU and RAM resources, they are not related to CUDA resources.

Yes, default workers for systems that support it is 8 per process, if your system has less workers available the worker count is correspondingly reduced. For best results we recommend you train on a system with at least 8 workers.

For large nodes with many CPUs available you can start independent trainings and assign 8-16 workers per training perhaps for best results, i.e. AWS P3 instances have 96 CPUs available over 8 GPUs, which allows you to train 8 single-GPU runs in parallel with CPU resources left over for extra tasks not related to dataloading.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26833433/109585366-43808780-7ab8-11eb-9269-de49aef48e53.png)

@glenn-jocher ,
Thank you!

on my computer, the CPU is 10700K which has 8 cores with 16 threads totally.
I am quite sure more than 4 threads are available for my training. 

I am confused what HW resource is insufficient. even if there is resource insufficient issue, it should not be on CUDA but on CPU.

Is there a way to diagnose/monitor what resource is insufficient?

@ardeal if you are on linux you can use `htop` command to see the same screenshot. But yes if you have 16 threads then you should have 16 workers available. I would restart your system and if there are any issues they may be environment related. You might try the docker image if you want to train locally in a verified environment: It appears you may have environment problems. Please ensure you meet all dependency requirements if you are attempting to run YOLOv5 locally. If in doubt, create a new virtual Python 3.8 environment, clone the latest repo (**code changes daily**), and `pip install -r requirements.txt` again. We also highly recommend using one of our verified environments below. ## Requirements **Python 3.8** or later with all [requirements.txt](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/blob/master/requirements.txt) dependencies installed, including **`torch>=1.7`**. To install run: ```bash $ pip install -r requirements.txt ``` ## Environments YOLOv5 may be run in any of the following up-to-date verified environments (with all dependencies including [CUDA](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda)/[CUDNN](https://developer.nvidia.com/cudnn), [Python](https://www.python.org/) and [PyTorch](https://pytorch.org/) preinstalled): - **Google Colab and Kaggle** notebooks with free GPU: - **Google Cloud** Deep Learning VM. See [GCP Quickstart Guide](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/wiki/GCP-Quickstart) - **Amazon** Deep Learning AMI. See [AWS Quickstart Guide](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/wiki/AWS-Quickstart) - **Docker Image**. See [Docker Quickstart Guide](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/wiki/Docker-Quickstart) ## Status ![CI CPU testing](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/workflows/CI%20CPU%20testing/badge.svg) If this badge is green, all [YOLOv5 GitHub Actions](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/actions) Continuous Integration (CI) tests are passing. These tests evaluate proper operation of basic YOLOv5 functionality, including training ([train.py](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/blob/master/train.py)), testing ([test.py](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/blob/master/test.py)), inference ([detect.py](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/blob/master/detect.py)) and export ([export.py](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/blob/master/models/export.py)) on MacOS, Windows, and Ubuntu.

@glenn-jocher ，
Thank you!


I am training YOLOv3 on my local computer.

I confirm I have all necessary packages satisfied.

I have also try to restart and re-train the code for several times. The same CUDA out of memory issue happened.
@ardeal try docker image, reduce batch size.

@glenn-jocher ,

I changed num_workers = 4, and batch_size = 8, and re-train. I still encountered the same issue.

The packages I installed on my computer are:

@glenn-jocher ，

I add 32GB RAM to my computer. now, I could set num_workers = 4 and batch_size=32. The code could be trained correctly.

So, the CUDA out of memory issue is not related with CUDA but with CPU RAM.  

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6227348/110095605-0da11300-7dd8-11eb-9983-79bda92dd146.png)
@ardeal that's strange! Thanks for the update.

@glenn-jocher ,

I tried the following:


  | num_workers=1 | num_workers = 2 | num_workers = 4 | num_workers = 8
-- | -- | -- | -- | --
CPU | 10700K | 10700K | 10700K | 10700K
CPU   RAM(G) | 16 | 16 | 48 | 48
CPU RAM   used(G) | 9.5 | 9.5 | 12 | CUDA out of memory issue
GPU | 3090 | 3090 | 3090 | 3090
GPU   RAM(G) | 24 | 24 | 24 | 24
GPU RAM   used(G) | 17.5 | 17.5 | 17.9 | CUDA out of memory issue
GPU   Power(w) | 257 | 357 | 357 | CUDA out of memory issue
image count | 10180 | 10180 | 10180 | 10180
epoch | 100 | 100 | 100 | 100
batch   size | 32 | 32 | 32 | 32
batch   count | 319 | 319 | 319 | 319
total   time for training(hours) | 15 | 6.459 | 6.05 |  
time for   each epoch(minutes) | 9 | 3.875 | 3.6333 |  
average   time for batch(second) | 1.69 | 0.73 | 0.617 |  

I have 2 doubts:
1) the training speed of num_workers=2 is quite faster than that of num_workers=1, however, there small difference for num_workers=2 and 4.
2) when num_workers=2, there are much CPU ram and GPU ram left, num_workers=8 doesn't work. it is very weird.
@ardeal seems about right, I don't see any major problems. Windows is not the best environment for ML though as you probably know, so if possible I would always try to train in a docker container.
